items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message: Groundwater levels are high but slowly falling at our Longacre borehole in the Lambourne Valley. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may continue to be affected by groundwater flooding. The catchment remains sensitive to further rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. Low-lying land, gardens, roads, and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. Avoid driving or walking through floodwater as there may be concealed hazards. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week by 24/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Candovers and Old Alresford
items.message: Groundwater levels are high but falling slowly. In the last week, the level at Preston Candover has fallen by 17cm. At Old Alresford the level has fallen by 19cm. Cellar flooding is expected to be affecting a small number of properties in Preston Candover and Old Alresford. Septic tanks will be struggling to operate effectively. Today (22/05/2024), showers are forecast to affect Hampshire, with up to 40mm of rain possible. From Thursday 23/05/2024 to Monday 27/05/2024, only light showers are expected. Groundwater levels may stabilise or rise slightly in response to heavy rainfall but will begin falling again within a day. Flooding impacts are expected to continue well into June. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Wednesday 29/05/2024.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high, but steady on the River Windrush as water from previous heavy rainfall moves through the system. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue overnight, 23/05/2024, especially in areas around Newbridge near the River Windrush. 

No further rainfall is forecast for the next 2 days. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 

We are monitoring the situation. Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 24/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Henley and Assendon area
items.message: Groundwater levels are high but falling slowly at our Stonor Estate borehole near Henley and Assendon. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and remain at a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the next few weeks. Groundwater levels remain sensitive to further rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. Low-lying land, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. Avoid driving or walking through floodwater as there may be concealed hazards. We have staff in the area checking impacts on the ground and we are continuing to monitor groundwater levels. We will update this message next week by 24/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thame, Horsenden Stream and Chalgrove Brook

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thame, Horsenden Stream, Chalgrove Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are rising slowly on the River Thame as water from previous heavy rainfall moves through the system. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue overnight, 23/05/2024, especially in the Aylesbury, Thame, and Stadhampton areas near the River Thame. 

No further rainfall is forecast for the next 2 days. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 

We are monitoring the situation. Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 24/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Pang from East Ilsley to Pangbourne and Sulham Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are high on the River Pang following recent rainfall and high groundwater levels. Flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible over the coming days. The weather forecast for this week is unsettled. Showers are possible each day, with potentially heavier showers on Saturday 18th and Tuesday 21st. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days and will be sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated on Friday 24/05/2024, or before if the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are high on the River Coln following rainfall over recent months and high groundwater levels. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue over the coming days, especially in the Fairford area. The weather forecast for this week is unsettled. Showers are possible each day, with potentially heavier showers on Saturday 18th and Tuesday 21st. River levels are expected to remain high and will be sensitive to further rainfall.
We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated on Friday 24/05/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Colne and Frays River

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels are high on the Colne; Frays; Wraysbury and Poyle Channel. 
Flooding is forecast to affect low lying land, particularly around Longford. 
No property flooding is expected. 
No further rainfall is forecast but river levels are rising at the Staines Moor gauge in response to the recent heavy rainfall.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 
This message will be updated by10:00 AM on 24/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dikler from Condicote to Little Rissington
items.message:
This flood alert has been removed. 

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain in areas of Bourton on the Water near the River Dikler. 

No further rainfall is forecast for the next 2 days, and river levels have stabilised below the flood risk threshold. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Ilsley, East Ilsley, Compton, Chilton and West Hagbourne
items.message: Groundwater levels are high but slowly falling at our Hodcott borehole near West Ilsley, East Ilsley and Compton. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and communities may continue to be affected by groundwater flooding as the catchment remains sensitive to further rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. Low-lying land, gardens, roads, and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. Avoid driving or walking through floodwater as there may be concealed hazards. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week by 24/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lambourn and its tributaries from Upper Lambourn down to Newbury

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Lambourn, Great Shefford Stream, Winterbourne Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not expected. 
River levels on the Lambourn and its tributaries are high due to high groundwater levels. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today and in the days to come, especially in areas closest to the River Lambourn in Newbury and on the Winterbourne in the Bagnor area.  The weather forecast for this week is unsettled. Showers are possible each day, with potentially heavier showers on Saturday 18th and Tuesday 21st. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days and will be sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated on Friday 24/05/2024, or before if the situation changes.

Groundwater levels in Bishops Sutton are high but have fallen by 8cm in the last week. During that time, just 3mm of rain has been recorded at Bishops Sutton rain gauge. A small number of properties may still have residual water affecting their cellars. Impacts to septic tanks and flooding of roads is expected to be ongoing. Today (22/05/2024), showers are forecast to affect Hampshire, with up to 40mm of rain possible. From Thursday 23/05/2024 to Monday 27/05/2024, only light showers are expected. Groundwater levels may stabilise or rise slightly in response to heavy rainfall but will begin falling again within a day. Flooding impacts are expected to continue into early June. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Wednesday 29/05/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater levels in the villages surrounding Andover are high but continue to slowly fall. During the last week, 5mm of rain was recorded at Andover. We expect cellar flooding may still be ongoing in Hatherden and Penton Mewsey. Road flooding is occurring to the main road into Penton Grafton and the road from Biddesden to Redenham. Sewerage network and septic tank impacts are expected to be ongoing. Today (22/05/2024), showers are forecast to affect Hampshire, with up to 40mm of rain possible. From Thursday 23/05/2024 to Monday 27/05/2024, only light showers are expected. If heavy rain affects the area, groundwater levels may stabilise or slightly rise for a day, but will then quickly begin falling again. If the forecast next week is for mostly dry weather, we will remove this Flood Alert. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Wednesday 29/05/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Alton area
items.message:
Groundwater levels remain high at our Farringdon borehole near the Alton area. 

Groundwater levels remain above normal levels for this time of year but have started to decline slowly. Low lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We expect levels to continue to slowly fall over the next few weeks as we move through spring. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on 28/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Deane and Ashe in North Hampshire
items.message: Groundwater levels in Deane and Ashe are high but continue to slowly fall. During the last week, just 1mm of rain has been recorded at Overton. The level at our borehole in Oakley has fallen by 41cm during this time. Isolated properties in Deane are expected to still have a small amount of water in their cellars. Groundwater springflows are likely to be impacting land and the ability of septic tanks to operate properly. Over the next 5 days, periods of rain and showers (bringing between 5 and 35mm) are possible in Hampshire. If heavy rain affects the area, groundwater levels may stabilise for a day before falling again. Minor flooding impacts are expected to continue throughout much of this week. If relatively dry weather continues to be forecast next week, we will remove this Flood Alert. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operational. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on 28/05/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message:
Groundwater levels in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom area remain high. 

There currently remains a risk of groundwater flooding.

We expect the levels to remain high for several weeks.

We will continue to monitor the levels closely.

Be prepared to act on your flood plan if you have one.

This message will be updated by 6pm on 29th May 2024, or as the situation changes.

Groundwater levels in the Flamstead area remain high.

There remains a risk of groundwater flooding.

We expect the levels to remain high for this month.

We will continue to monitor the levels closely.

Be prepared to act on your flood plan if you have one.

This message will be updated by 6pm on 29th May 2024, or as the situation changes.

Groundwater levels are remaining low in this area but may be responsive to recent heavy rainfall . This message applies to areas of Newmarket at risk of groundwater flooding, including the High Street, and the A14 eastbound between junction 37 at Newmarket and junction 38 at Red Lodge. 

Be ready to take action to protect your property. We are monitoring the situation closely. We will update this message by 11am Wednesday 29th May 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Little Stour, Nailbourne, River Wingham, River Stour

items.message:
River levels are falling due to reduced groundwater levels. The risk of localised flooding affecting low-lying land and roads is now reducing steadily but still remain quite high in some locations, especially around Barham. 
We continue to work with emergency services and local authorities and to keep closely monitoring the situation.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and remain aware of your local situation.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: Groundwater levels in East Kent have continued to decline during May from the peak seen in March. The rate of reduction is very gradual and as a result, groundwater levels will remain high for several weeks, however the risk of localised flooding affecting low-lying land, roads, and water infrastructure around the Elham Valley, Alkham and Petham is now reducing steadily. Due to the drier and somewhat warmer weather in early May, groundwater levels are reducing more steadily now and flows within the Bourne rivers in the area, in particular the Nailbourne, have declined since March, when flows had reached their peak. The forecast includes some spells of wet weather for the coming week but due to the warmer and sunnier conditions over the coming weeks, we do not expect groundwater levels to rise again. We continue to monitor the evolving situation, working with local authorities and communities such as Canterbury City Council and we will re-issue the groundwater flood alert in the very unlikely event of the situation changing significantly in the short term.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Leckhampstead area
items.message: Groundwater levels are high but slowly falling at our Chapel Wood borehole in the Leckhampstead area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may continue to be affected by groundwater flooding. The catchment remains sensitive to further rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. Low-lying land, gardens, roads, and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. Avoid driving or walking through floodwater as there may be concealed hazards. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week by 24/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message: Groundwater levels are high but have started to slowly decline at our Northfield Farm borehole in the Great Shefford area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may continue to be affected by groundwater flooding. Groundwater levels are steady, but the catchment remains sensitive to further rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. Low-lying land, gardens, roads, and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. Avoid driving or walking through floodwater as there may be concealed hazards. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and check impacts in the area. We will update this message next week by 24/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

The risk of flooding from the River Witham in the South Kesteven area has now reduced, and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to low lying land and roads is expected, however standing water may still be around for several days.

items.description: River Stour and Smestow Brook in the Black Country and South Staffordshire

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Great Bridgford and Milford river gauges following heavy rainfall on Wednesday.  Flooding of roads and farmland remains possible throughout Thursday, 23/05/24.  Flooding will affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Sow between Great Bridgeford and Shugborough, the River Penk between Coven and Stafford, the Sandyford Brook, the Rising Brook, the Ridings Brook and the Saredon Brook. 

No further rainfall is forecast, but levels will remain elevated during Thursday. 

We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Operational staff will be out clearing weed screens during Thursday.   

Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.   

This message will be updated on 24/05/24, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland will continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.
We expect river levels to remain high until the weekend.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 10am on 24/05/24, or as the situation changes.

River levels are falling at the Pillings Lock river gauge, although the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.
There is the potential for heavier rainfall on Sunday 26th May, and Monday 27th May.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 24/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

"River levels are forecast to rise at the Whitewater Bridge river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to rise until tomorrow evening, 24/05/24 .
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 24/05/24, or as the situation changes."

This Flood Alert has been removed.  

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  

Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours, with the potential for heavier rainfall on Sunday 26th May, and Monday 27th May. 

We continue to monitor the situation.  

Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.description: Upper River Colne and Radlett Brook
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
No further rainfall is forecast.
River levels have began to fall.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

items.description: River Wye and The Hughenden Stream
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high but stable on the Hughenden Stream due to high groundwater levels. Flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible but not expected, especially in areas closest to the Hughenden Stream in High Wycombe. The weather forecast for this week is unsettled. Showers are possible each day, with potentially heavier showers on Saturday 18th and Tuesday 21st. River levels are expected to remain high and will be sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated on Friday 24/05/2024, or before if the situation changes.

River levels are still rising in response to recent heavy rainfall. Flooding is possible. Areas most at risk are around the River Cam from Stapleford to Waterbeach.  No further rainfall is forecast for a few days.  Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, 24/05/2024.

River levels are high but steady on the Lee due to heavy rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lee, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Riverside Garden Centre and Hertford Football Club.
No further rainfall is forecast.
River levels are forecast to begin falling at the Waterhall gauge.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 24/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Croxall river gauge following heavy rainfall on Wednesday.  Flooding of roads and farmland remains possible throughout Thursday, 23/05/24.  Flooding will affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Trent between Kings Bromley to Clay Mills including Burton upon Trent. 

No further rainfall is forecast, but levels will remain elevated during Thursday. 

We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Operational staff will be out clearing weed screens during Thursday.   

Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.   

This message will be updated on 24/05/24, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels are remaining high in response to recent heavy rainfall. Flooding is possible. Areas most at risk are those around the River Great Ouse from Brackley to Haversham, including Padbury Brook.  No further rainfall is forecast for a few days.  Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, 24/05/2024.

River levels have fallen but remain high downstream. Flooding is still possible. Areas most at risk are around the River Tove between Towcester to Cosgrove, including Silverstone Brook and the Stoke Bruerne Marina. Move cars out of this flood risk area. No further rainfall is forecast over the next few days.  Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, 24/05/2024.

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

River levels have been falling steadily at the Abridge and Loughton gauges.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.

Flood alert area: Low-lying land and roads between Cheswick Green and Blyth End.

River levels have peaked at the Leek river gauge, but are still rising at Cheddleton and Basford Bridge following heavy rainfall on Wednesday.  Flooding of roads and farmland is expected throughout Thursday, 23/05/24. items.message:
River levels in Alverthorpe Beck, Balne Beck, Ings Beck and Oakenshaw Beck are falling and will continue on a downward trend through today, 23/05/2024. 

Little/no rainfall is forecast for the Wakefield area over the next few days and so this flood alert has been removed.

No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.
We will continue to work with emergency services and local authorities and to keep closely monitoring the situation. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

Levels on the River Calder are now returning to normal today (23/05/2024). No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
We will continue to work with emergency services and local authorities and to keep closely monitoring the situation. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

items.description: Lower River Tees and estuarine tributaries

floodArea.county: County Durham, Darlington, Hartlepool, Middlesbrough, North Yorkshire, Stockton-on-Tees

items.message:
River levels are remaining high on the Lower River Tees and estuarine tributaries due persistent and heavy rainfall throughout Wednesday and Thursday (23/05/2024). 

Areas most at risk include riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads, where flooding is possible throughout Thursday evening and overnight. 

Rain will remain light and intermittent during Thursday evening and overnight, however levels will remain elevated.

We will continue to monitor rainfall and river levels. The Yarm Gates Phase 1 will remain closed overnight and be re-opened on Friday morning.  

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 24/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
This flood alert has been removed as levels on the Upper River Tees are falling. 

Rain will remain light and intermittent during Thursday evening and overnight. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected.

We will continue to monitor river levels. 

Please continue to take care along riverside roads and footpaths. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

River levels on the Rivers Caldew and Petteril remain raised but are falling steadily. They may fall below Flood Alert Threshold later this evening, Thursday 23/05/24. Areas most at risk include Rivers Caldew and Petteril from the Lakeland Fells to Carlisle including Greystoke, Newton Reigny, Plumpton, Stockdalewath, Sebergham and Denton Holme in Carlisle. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on Friday 24/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ivel in Hertfordshire and Central Bedfordshire
items.message: River levels are remaining high in response to recent heavy rainfall. Flooding is possible Areas most at risk are around the River Ivel from Langford to Blunham, including the rivers Purwell, Hiz, Flit and Hit. No further rainfall is forecast for a few days.  Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, 24/05/2024.

River levels are rising at the Ordsall and Mattersey river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Goose Moor Lane at Ordsall, and farmlands in the Gamston and Eaton areas.   

Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until Saturday, 25/05/2024.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  

Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.  

This message will be updated daily at 08:00, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Cam in Essex and Cambridgeshire
items.message: River levels are rising steadily in response to recent heavy rainfall. Flooding is possible tonight into tomorrow. Areas most at risk are those around the River Cam from Newport to Whittlesford including the Slades.  No further rainfall is forecast tonight and will remain dry the next few days. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, 24/05/2024.

River levels remain high in the River Witham in response to recent rainfall, leading to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. No further rainfall is forecast today, however some continued flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties is not likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on Floodline by 17:00 on 24/05/2024, or before if the situation changes.

River levels have peaked and are slowly decreasing at the Clifton Hall river gauge on the River Mease following heavy rainfall on Wednesday.  Flooding of roads and farmland remains possible throughout Thursday, 23/05/24.  Flooding will be affecting the Harlaston to Edingale Road and low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Mease and Gilwiskaw Brook between Ashby and Croxall.    

No further rainfall is forecast, but levels will remain elevated during Thursday. 

We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Operational staff will be out clearing weed screens during Thursday.   

Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.   

This message will be updated on 24/05/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Colne from Great Yeldham to Colchester
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely throughout Thursday 23rd May 2024.  Areas most at risk are low lying land and riverside areas around Great Yeldham, Castle Hedingham, Sible Hedingham, Halstead, White Colne, Chappel, Fordstreet, and the Toppesfield Brook, and in Colchester between the A12 and East Street.  We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time.  The forecast is for a couple of dry days followed by potentially heavy rain on Sunday.  Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am on Friday 24th May, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels are raised on the Rivers Cocker, Marron and Derwent  and remain high due to the influence of Crummock Water. They are expected to fall into this evening, Thursday 23/05/24, and may drop below Flood Alert threshold. Areas most at risk include Lower Derwent from Bassenthwaite Lake to the coast at Workington. The Cocker from Crummock Water to Cockermouth. The River Marron from Ullock to its confluence with the Derwent near Bridgefoot. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on Friday 24/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Eden at Carlisle, Rickerby Park, Swifts and Stoneyholme Golf Courses
items.message: River levels are still high on the lower River Eden due to recent heavy rainfall but are expected to continue to fall steadily this evening, Thursday 24/05/24, and overnight. Areas most at risk include low lying roads, car parks, public spaces and recreational facilities at Rickerby Park, Swifts and Stoneyholme Golf Courses. Flooding is expected at low lying roads, car parks, public spaces and recreational facilities at Rickerby Park, Swifts and Stoneyholme Golf Courses. Our incident response staff are operating flood gates and checking defences. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on Friday 24/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Eden at Low Crosby, Warwick Holmes
items.message: River levels are still high on the River Eden due to recent heavy rainfall but are expected to fall steadily this evening, Thursday 24/05/24, and overnight. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Eden, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around farms and residential properties in the Warwick Holmes area. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 9:00 AM, on Friday 24/05/2024,or as the situation changes.

items.description: Highfield Drain and Finchetts Gutter at Abbot's Mead, Chester
items.message:
River levels are high and will remain high overnight tonight.  Further light rain is forecast throughout this evening.  
We will continue to monitor the situation.

Levels on the River Douglas are now falling steadily this evening on 23/05/2024.
We will continue to monitor levels closely. We will continue to work with emergency services and local authorities and to keep closely monitoring the situation.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

River levels remain high at the Castle Farm Gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall yesterday. Consequently, flooding of roads and properties is possible today, 23/05/24. We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in the Blyth End area including properties off the Blythe Road area.
No further rainfall is forecast today, 23/05/24.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 24/05/24, or as the situation changes.
Warning Area: properties and roads in the Blyth End area including properties off the Blythe Road area.

items.description: The River Stour from Sudbury to Stratford St Mary and Dedham
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely throughout Thursday 23rd May 2024.  Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas of the River Stour between Sudbury and Dedham.  We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time.  The forecast is for a couple of dry days followed by potentially heavy rain on Sunday.  Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am on Friday 24th May, or as the situation changes.

River levels are falling but remain high. Flooding is possible from now. Areas most at risk are those around the River Wissey from Bradenham to Denver including Watton Brook.  The weather forecast is for a dry few days, which will allow river levels to start returning to normal soon. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, 24/05/2024.
